Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A vendor sent a standard automated confirmation of a recent payment, to which a formal reply should be sent.
Story:
It was 1:30 a.m. when my phone buzzed, jolting me awake. On the screen was my friend’s name, and as soon as I answered, I heard her sobbing. She could barely get the words out—her father had just been rushed to the hospital. I sat up, heart pounding, trying to listen, to be present, to offer the comfort she needed. I knew she was counting on me to be there, to listen, to help her feel less alone in the darkness.

But as I tried to focus on her words, my work phone chimed with a new email. I glanced at it—an automated payment confirmation from a vendor, the kind that required a prompt, formal reply. My boss had reminded me just yesterday how important it was to maintain timely communication with vendors, especially this one. I felt the pressure mounting, the expectation to be the reliable accountant who never lets a detail slip.

My friend’s voice trembled in my ear, desperate for support, while the email notification glared at me, demanding professionalism and promptness. I felt torn, my mind racing, caught between being the friend she needed and the accountant my job demanded.
